pullRequest.body:
`M` is a scalar matrix if it commutes with every non-diagonal `stdBasisMatrix`.

Co-authored-by: Eric Wieser <wieser.eric@gmail.com>

---

GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

nodes.body: Note: I have pushed an update to the lean toolchain because this PR was on a [buggy version](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113488-general/topic/Potential.20data.20loss.20from.20.60lake.20clean.60.20with.204.2E2.2E0-rc2.2F3/near/397875701) of the toolchain. **WARNING**: checking out old commits of this PR using v4.2.0-rc2 or v4.2.0-rc3 can cause `lake clean` to delete your mathlib folder! If you need to do so, make sure to delete `lakefile.olean` manually before running any `lake` commands.
#7833 is related here, but I don't think it directly helps.

maintainer merge

I think we should just land this; if @shuxuezhuyi really needs the `M = M default default â€¢ (1 : Matrix n n Î±) ` spelling of `M âˆˆ Set.range (Matrix.scalar n)`, it can always come in a follow-up PR.
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by eric-wieser.
Canceled.

bors merge

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

A little more concise as
```suggestion
    (hM : Commute (stdBasisMatrix i j 1) M) (hkj : k â‰  j) : M j k = 0 := by
```
And below
Thanks! I am really sorry that the APP didn't notify me.

~~Sorry, I now realize that this comment was incorrect; your original spelling was actually better, because it generalizes to rectangular matrices!~~

Nevermind, that is of course nonsense

Some name suggestions:
```suggestion
theorem row_eq_zero_of_commute_stdBasisMatrix {i j k : n} {M : Matrix n n Î±}
    (hM : Commute (stdBasisMatrix i j 1) M) (hkj : k â‰  j) : M j k = 0 := by
  have := Matrix.ext_iff.mpr hM i k
  aesop

theorem col_eq_zero_of_commute_stdBasisMatrix {i j k : n} {M : Matrix n n Î±}
    (hM : Commute (stdBasisMatrix i j 1) M) (hki : k â‰  i) : M k i = 0 := by
  have := Matrix.ext_iff.mpr hM k j
  aesop

theorem diag_eq_of_commute_stdBasisMatrix {i j : n} {M : Matrix n n Î±}
    (hM : Commute (stdBasisMatrix i j 1) M) : M i i = M j j := by
  have := Matrix.ext_iff.mpr hM i j
  aesop
```
I think a better statement would be that `M \in Set.range Matrix.scalar` or similar, as that has the advantage of not needing `Inhabited n`

Unfortunately, that just turns `Inhabited n` into `Inhabited Î±`. I think it's fine to assume `Inhabited n` directly.  As long as we have `Nonempty n`, we can simply use `Classical.inhabited_of_nonempty â€¹_â€º` to obtain `Inhabited n`. Moreover, usually we use `Fin n` where n > 0, in which case `Inhabited (Fin n)` holds automatically since there is an instance in `Mathlib/Logic/Unique.lean`.
Now I have restated it and removed `Inhabited n`.

[](url)

> Unfortunately, that just turns `Inhabited n` into `Inhabited Î±`.

I don't know what you mean by this. You shouldn't need `Inhabited Î±`, you can just use `1` or `0`.

@eric-wieser I thought you wanted me to derive `Nonempty n` from `M : Matrix n n Î±`.
In this PR, it was initially expressed as `âˆƒ (c : Î±), M = c â€¢ (1 : Matrix n n Î±)`, which is not much different from `M âˆˆ Set.range (Matrix.scalar n)`. Later, I changed it to `M = M default default â€¢ (1 : Matrix n n Î±)` to make it easier to use in the tactic `rewrite`.
To remove the assumption of `Inhabited n`, I changed it to `(i : n) : M = M i i â€¢ (1 : Matrix n n Î±)`. This is equivalent to `âˆ€ (i : n), M = M i i â€¢ (1 : Matrix n n Î±)`, and it holds even if `n` is empty. When `n` is non-empty, I believe this form provides quite precise information and is more user-friendly.
In my opinion, when we want to handle the case where `n` is empty, we should directly jump to `M = 1`, rather than trying invoke this theorem. From this perspective, I think even `Inhabited n` is acceptable.
I believe that `(i : n) : M = M i i â€¢ (1 : Matrix n n Î±)` is a better expression. But I agree that the theorem could be renamed to `mem_range_scalar_of_commute_stdBasisMatrix`.
Oh! The case where `n` is empty and `Î±` is non-empty is really confusing! ~~There should be a theorem that tells us Matrix n n Î± is isomorphic to Î± in this case.~~

> There should be a theorem that tells us `Matrix n n Î±` is isomorphic to `Î±` in this case.

I find that hard to believe, given such a theorem is false! It's isomorphic to `Unit` instead.

> Later, I changed it to `M = M default default â€¢ (1 : Matrix n n Î±)` to make it easier to use in the tactic `rewrite`.

My claim is that this is actually less useful, as it contains `M` on both sides so is hard to rewrite by. The `Set.range` version can be used with `cases`, and it will substitute all the `M`s globally for some scalar `r`

> The `Set.range` version can be used with `cases`, and it will substitute all the `M`s globally for some scalar `r`

Fine. I will get used to it.

> I find that hard to believe, given such a theorem is false! It's isomorphic to `Unit` instead.

Wait, what do you think of `subsingleton_of_empty_left` in `Mathlib/Data/Matrix/Basic.lean`?
That tells us that when the index type is empty, then all matrices are `0`
